hints_html:
Think about the first examples of power series that you learned, and try to modify it.

Recall \(\displaystyle \frac{1}{1-t} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^n\).

Don’t forget the constant of integration!
hints_latex:
Think about the first examples of power series that you learned, and try
to modify it.
Don't forget the constant of integration!
hints_raw:
Think about the first examples of power series that you learned, and try to modify it.
Recall <math> \displaystyle \frac{1}{1-t} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^n </math>.
Don't forget the constant of integration!
question: 10 (a)
sols_html:
Since

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{1-t} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^n\end{aligned}\]

we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{1+x^3} = \frac{1}{1-(-x^3)} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-x^3)^n = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^nx^{3n}\end{aligned}\]

Integrating term by term,

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx &= \int \left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^nx^{3n}\right) \ dx \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \int (-1)^nx^{3n} \ dx \\ &= \left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}x^{3n+1}\right) + C\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Since

:<math> \displaystyle \frac{1}{1-t} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^n </math>

we have

:<math> \displaystyle 
\frac{1}{1+x^3} = \frac{1}{1-(-x^3)} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-x^3)^n = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^nx^{3n} </math>

Integrating term by term,

:<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\int \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx & = \int \left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^nx^{3n}\right) \ dx \\
& = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \int (-1)^nx^{3n} \ dx \\
& = \left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}x^{3n+1}\right) + C
\end{align}
</math>
